pages.text: Eucritta melanolimnetes comes from the lower Carboniferous, with fossils being found in the East Kirkton Quarry, Scotland (United Kingdom). It is a small Stem-tetropod, growing up to 25 cm in length. When first studied, the fossil specimens bore certain characteristics from early-reptiliomorphs, temnospondyls and baphetids, showing that these three orders diverged during the Carboniferous, rather than in the Devonian as previously thought.

The generic name derives from the Greek word 'eu', to mean 'true'; and American vernacular 'critta', to mean 'creature'. The specific name derives from the Greek words 'melano', to mean 'black'; and 'limnetes', to mean 'lagoon'.
